docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline.main: Wednesday Reading: Adding Adult Children to a Parent's Plan

docs.abstract: When adult children can be added to a parent's health insurance plan, what the frugal traveler has learned over the years and other consumer-focused items from Wednesday's Times.
docs.snippet: When adult children can be added to a parent's health insurance plan, what the frugal traveler has learned over the years and other consumer-focused items from Wednesday's Times.

headline.main: Which Adult Children Can Be Added to a Parent's Plan?

docs.abstract: There are few restrictions in the new law preventing parents from adding adult children to their insurance plans, so long as the children are under age 26.
docs.snippet: There are few restrictions in the new law preventing parents from adding adult children to their insurance plans, so long as the children are under age 26.

docs.news_desk: Dining In, Dining Out / Style Desk
docs.lead_paragraph: John Ameroso has been showing New Yorkers how to grow what they eat since 1976 as an extension agent for the city. He is answering questions on growing food. Q. Beginners' question: Is there any food can you grow when you have more shade than sun to work with (like only morning sun)?

docs.abstract: The political process favors deferring the cost of labor contracts for years and also making the contracts harder to assess, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: The political process favors deferring the cost of labor contracts for years and also making the contracts harder to assess, an economist writes.

docs.abstract: Maternity care must be covered by plans offered in the exchanges, by small employers and in the individual market beginning in 2014.
docs.snippet: Maternity care must be covered by plans offered in the exchanges, by small employers and in the individual market beginning in 2014.

docs.lead_paragraph: Alexandra Drane was one of the many entrepreneurs who thought she could do it all. Ms. Drane is co-founder and president of Eliza Corporation, a firm based in Beverly, Mass., that uses patented technology to communicate with health plan members, often with automated calls to encourage them to take advantage of the services their plans offer. She joined Eliza in 1999, when it consisted of just two scientists and a technology that she was charged with commercializing. She recruited the chief executive, Lucas Merrow, and by 2004, Eliza had hired engineering and operations teams. But when it came to Ms. Drane's responsibilities -- sales, marketing and account management -- she was largely a solo operator. That was around the time, she said, that a board member read her "the riot act," insisting that the company would not be able to achieve scale until she started hiring.

headline.main: Finding the Nerve to Make That Hire

docs.abstract: Taking time out of any one day to focus on hiring felt inefficient. But that shortsighted reaction was the true inefficiency.
docs.snippet: Taking time out of any one day to focus on hiring felt inefficient. But that shortsighted reaction was the true inefficiency.
